text: [music playing]

ELENI GIOKOS: Nestled in
the northwest of Nairobi,

within a glass,
steel-columned building,

it's a plan that has been
fermenting for a while.

Tabitha, we're in your
newly-expanded area.
This cost $50 million.

This is Keroche Breweries,
home of Summit beer,

where, through the roaring
sounds of machines humming

and glass bottles
clinking, this beer-maker

is tapping into Kenya's
lucrative alcohol business.

TABITHA KARANJA: So, my job
now is to make sure that I can
turn this liquid into money.

ELENI GIOKOS: Tabitha
Karanja is the CEO

of Keroche Breweries, which
she founded with her husband
nearly 20 years ago.

Despite not having a
background in the industry,

Karanja says she recognized
that a part of the market
was neglected.

TABITHA KARANJA:
[inaudible] mostly was
considered in the lower market.

So, we came up with
[inaudible] vodka.
And then we have our beers now.

We have two only, but the
machines that you see here
can produce [inaudible] brands.

ELENI GIOKOS: In Kenya, 22.8%
of men and 9.6% of women

drink, according to the
World Health Organization.

To serve this
thirsty population,

Karanja says she
got a $50 million

loan from Barclays in 2015
to expand its production

levels from 10 million
liters of beer per year
to 110 million liters.

TABITHA KARANJA: We
knew we did ten-fold
of whatever we had done.

We had enough--
we had the market
to distribute this market.

And because of--
the reason for this

is because the beer
is naturally brewed,

and is the first one to
be done in this country
that has no sugar added.

So, giving a choice to the
people, that was more premium.

ELENI GIOKOS: But even with
Keroche Breweries' expansion,

it only controls 2% of
Kenya's beer market.

There's one company
leading the pack by far.

East African Breweries
Limited, which

is part of the multinational
alcohol beverage company

Diageo, has been in the
country for 94 years,
and has 71% market share.

ANDREW COWAN: EABL is a
really important contributor
to the Kenyan environment.

We also have over
100 distributors,

and we're the second
largest contributor
to the Kenyan treasury.

ELENI GIOKOS: Gaining that
kind of growth wasn't easy.

EABL survived a
beer war in Kenya

during the late 1990s,
which led to the exit
of its main rival, SABMiller.

Today, the company's Tusker
brand is one of the most
popular beers in East Africa.

ANDREW COWAN: All
this competition means

is that you've got to be better
at giving consumers what they
desire than the competition.

And therefore, it means
we focus on who matters
most, which is the consumers.

ELENI GIOKOS: Now, Keroche
Breweries hopes to become
a formidable competitor.

TABITHA KARANJA: When we compete
now fairly into the market,
have no fear.

Our beer [inaudible] the market
with the quality of my product.

ELENI GIOKOS: And
international brewers
are also entering the field.

Where are you selling
the most at the moment?

DANIEL MUNENE: The place
I'm selling most is Nairobi.

ELENI GIOKOS: Daniel Munene
is the Kenya distributor
for United Dutch Breweries.

It is the third largest
brewery in the Netherlands.

Its best-seller is Atlas,
which has a higher alcohol
content than most local beers.

DANIEL MUNENE: 12% is
serving in most pubs

at 200 Kenya shillings,
which is about $2.

Instead of spending about 600
shillings, you only spend 200.

So, you target those people
who want to drink responsibly,

who do not have a lot
of money in the pocket.

ELENI GIOKOS: UDB now imports
3,500 cans of beer to Kenya
each month.

DANIEL MUNENE: If we
increase the price,
you look at other competitors.

ELENI GIOKOS: As new
players enter the market,

the CEO of EABL says they
will expand the company's

signature brand in the future to
continue attracting consumers.

ANDREW COWAN: I think we'll have
a very, very healthy broader
Tusker trademark.

I think we will champion
interesting serves of spirits.

We will champion a
cocktail culture.

ELENI GIOKOS: And Karanja
has similar plans.

So, you want to go-- you want
to expand in East Africa.

What is your business gonna
look like in 10 years from now?

TABITHA KARANJA: 10 years
from now, I see myself,
my beer, the whole of Africa.

ELENI GIOKOS: The
whole of Africa.

TABITHA KARANJA:
[inaudible] yes.

ELENI GIOKOS: So,
in South Africa
I'll be able to buy Summit beer.

TABITHA KARANJA:
Yeah, yeah, you'll
be able to buy Summit beer.

ELENI GIOKOS: I look
forward to that.
Eleni Giokos, CNN, Nairobi.
ANDREW COWAN: Drink it chilled.
It's really great chilled.
Made of real apples.

ELENI GIOKOS: When
we return, the CEO

of East Africa Breweries tells
me more about the company's
success in Kenya.
Don't go away.
[music playing]
